thread.title: Luttrell, Shelby County Commission convene iron out budget and other confusion
thread.title_full: Luttrell, Shelby County Commission convene to iron out budget and other confusion

author: Linda A. Moore
title: Luttrell, Shelby County Commission convene iron out budget and other confusion
text:
A meeting between the county mayor and commissioners Friday had its origins in confusion and misunderstandings, but ended with an agreement to better communicate and to share priorities.
Shelby County Mayor Mark Luttrell and the County Commission held a joint budget summit meeting in the forests of west Shelby County at the St. Columba Episcopal Conference & Retreat Center.
Luttrell asked for the meeting with the commission after a contentious budget season that included conflicts over a failed property tax cut proposal and the use of revenues that came in above projections.
The conflicts showed the need for the administration and the commission to “sit down and kind of work through some of our issues,” Luttrell said at the opening of the meeting.
“We’ll continue to have bumps in the road, but that’s why you have these sessions, to work out the bumps,” he said after the half-day session ended.
The conversation touched on retooling the Economic Development Growth Engine board, interactions with administration division heads and varying interpretations of the county charter.
“I think we’ve made strides today,” commission chairman Terry Roland said. “I think maybe if we’d had been having these things all along, maybe we wouldn’t have had some of these problems.”
Getting the county’s priorities in order should be the theme going forward, Roland said, a sentiment also expressed by Commissioner Willie Brooks .
“I think it’s going very well,” Brooks said. “It’s a good discussion going forward. I think we need to continue this discussion as we set our priorities for the county.”
A primary focus was when and how revenue projections are made by staff with county chief financial officer Mike Swift and trustee David Lenoir .
Commissioners noted that this year, early projected revenue numbers were lower than the funds collected.
That situation could be remedied if the commission changed the date when the budget is due from March to April, Swift said.
Property taxes, the largest portion of the county’s revenues, are paid primarily in December, when mortgage companies send funds, and February, when taxes are late, Lenoir said.
But, with figures changing as late as June, in a fiscal year that ends June 30, Commissioner Heidi Shafer wanted to know when changes can be made to the budget before it is “set in stone.”
Meanwhile, Commissioner Mark Billingsley pushed for the commission to establish its own five-year plan, making the budget process one that also followed county goals.
“I feel totally reactive,” Billingsley said of how the commission is expected to respond to needs. “And I think we could be doing a better job if we had that three-to-five-year plan.”
While the Luttrell administration has a plan in place, commissioners said they should be a part of it, too.
Commissioners spent the early hours listening to Tony Saunders, chief restructuring officer and CFO for Wayne County, Mich., where he helped oversee Detroit’s financial recovery.
He spoke about addressing Shelby County Schools’ OPEB (other post-employment benefits) liabilities, which are now at $1.5 billion.
